results.title: Living free
results.creator_credit: Columbia, Carl Foreman, Paul Radin and Jack Couffer
results.brief_description: The sequel to “Born free” continues the adventures of Joy and George Adamson. Elsa the lioness brings her three cubs out of the wilderness to the couple who raised her. When Elsa suddenly dies, the cubs who cannot fend for themselves, attack domestic animals to survive before disappearing into the wild. The Adamson’s launch a desperate attempt to find the young lions and bring them to the safety of the game reserve. Starring Susan Hampshire and Nigel Davenport.

results.title: Live nude girls
results.creator_credit: Republic Pictures Corporation, Steve White Properties, Steve White, Barry Bernardi and Julianna Lavin
results.brief_description: Georgina, an attractive thirty-something, decides to hold a slumber party to celebrate the impending nuptials of her friend Jamie, a vain, B-grade actress getting married for the third time. Gathered together are several of their closest friends, all of whom have known each other since childhood. Questions of aging, parenthood, infidelity, low-self esteem, body image, bad partner choices, regrets, sexual orientation, defining childhood events, masturbation and squandered desires are workshopped over the course of the slumber party. All of the women assembled there are at transitional stages in their life, questioning the choices they have made: Georgina doubts her relationship with her female live-in lover, the perennially depressed Chris; Marcy is attempting to shake off a former lover who has taken to stalking her; Jill is pregnant with her second child. The many verbal exchanges reveal the petty jealousies that exist within the group, especially the rivalry between the straight-laced Rachel and her wilder and less inhibited sister, Jill. The friends discuss sex at great length, disclosing their fantasies, inhibitions, desires and sexual history. “Live nude girls” is a comedy that explores the territory of female sexuality, explicitly displaying the women’s numerous erotic fantasises and sexual experiences.

results.title: Live flesh = Carne tremula
results.creator_credit: El Deseo S. A., CiBy 2000, France 3, Agustin Almodovar and Pedro Almodovar
results.brief_description: Several lives are forever altered by a single gun shot. Wealthy heiress and drug addict Helena (Francesca Neri), is awaiting her drug dealer when she accidentally allows in her apartment Victor (Liberto Rabal), to whom she vaguely promised a date. In the confusion that ensues, two cops, David (Javier Bardem) and Sancho (Jose Sancho) arrive and a gun goes off. Four years later, Victor comes out of jail and goes looking for Helena who is now married to paraplegic David and runs a children’s shelter. Victor’s desire for vengeance is temporarily sidetracked when he meets Clara (Angela Molina), an attractive, unhappily married older woman, keen to assist Victor in his other ultimate goal in life - to become the world’s best lover! Departing from his usual camp style Almodovar’s foray into film noir weaves a web of guilty pleasures, unbridled passions and not-so-sweet revenge mixed with subtle references to Bunuel. Adapted from “Live Flesh” by Ruth Rendell. In Spanish with English sub-titles.

results.title: Little Women
results.brief_description: One of the most enduring of the Hollywood movie classics, “Little Women” is based on Louisa May Alcott’s beloved novel. It is the story of four sisters who grow up together in Massachusetts during the Civil War. We enter their world to share their joys and sorrows as they become the “little women” that their father so proudly calls them. Stars Katherine Hepburn, Douglas Montgomery, Paul Lukas, Joan Bennett, Frances Dee and Jean Parker.

results.title: Little Odessa
results.creator_credit: Immigrant Pictures (US), Paul Webster and James Gray
results.brief_description: A Jewish-Russian hitman, Joshua Shapira (Tim Roth) returns to his family in Brighton Beach, New York, on a job. The town is referred to as ‘Little Odessa’, so called because of the influence of the Russian mob. Joshua is not a welcome presence as he disappeared in disgrace years ago for his reputation as a hitman, only his younger brother Reuben (Edward Furlong) and terminally ill mother (Vanessa Redgrave) welcome his presence. Joshua must lay low as rumours spread around of his arrival and neither Joshua or his familyn are safe from the violence that’s brewing in Little Odessa. Cast also includes Maximilian Schell, Moira Kelly and Paul Guilfoyle.

results.title: Little Lord Fauntleroy
results.creator_credit: David O. Selznick and John Cromwell
results.brief_description: Cedric is a spoilt child brought up in Brooklyn in the 1880’s who inherits an English title and finds his life transformed. In his stately family home in England, Cedric wins over his stern grandfather (C. Aubrey Smith). Freddie Bartholomew stars in the title role and is well supported by Dolores Costello as his mother and Mickey Rooney as the bootblack.

results.title: Little Caesar
results.creator_credit: First National Pictures, Hal B Wallis and Mervyn LeRoy
results.brief_description: ‘Little Caesar’ made Edward G.Robinson a star and exemplified the 1930’s gangster movie. Robinson plays “little tough guy” Caesar Enrico Bandello, whom with his cohort Joe Massara played by Douglas Fairbanks Jr., head for the big city in pursuit of power and wealth. His ruthlessness sees him climb to the top over his rivals, but success is short-lived in a world filled with violence and corruption. Mervyn Le Roy hired three mobsters as advisors and the film’s authenticity is a testimony to his attention to detail and fascination for the subject matter.

results.title: Little Big Man
results.creator_credit: Hiller Productions, Stuart Millar and Arthur Penn
results.brief_description: Arthur Penn’s adaptation of Thomas Berger’s novel shifts from comedy to drama as it depicts the horrific effects of American Imperialism. 121-year-old Jack Crabb narrates the story as the sole white survivor of the battle of Little Big Horn which saw the fall of General George A. Custer. He recounts his life story beginning with his adoption by Cheyenne Indians, where he was taught to live peacefully with nature. He later finds himself once again in the white world and is taken in by a preacher and his wife for religious education and guidance. He swaps his bible for a gun and be-friends Wild Bill Hickock, only to abandon even that to settle down and marry. Returning to the Cheyenne by chance, Crabb finds that he prefers this life, but is soon made aware of the carnage wreaked by white man. Cast includes: Dusitn Hoffman, Faye Dunaway, Martin Balsam, Richard Mulligan, and Chief Dan George.

results.title: Limelight
results.creator_credit: Charles Chaplin and Celebrated Films Corporation
results.brief_description: The story of a washed-up music hall clown who regains confidence while helping a suicidal ballerina. This was Chaplin’s most personal film in turn nostalgic, melancholic and contemplative as he reflects on old age and the nature of art and comedy. There are only moments of humour (notably in tandem with Buster Keaton). Comedy is a tool for Chaplin’s larger enterprise of soul-searching and summing up. Cast also includes Claire Bloom and Nigel Bruce.

results.title: Lilya 4-ever = Lilya forever [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Memfis, Zentropa, Lars Jonsson and Lukas Moodysson
results.brief_description: Lukas Moodyson (Show me love, Together) delivers a bleak and melancholic story of a young Russian girl Lilya (Oksana Akinshina) who is abandoned by her mother (absconding to America with a boyfriend), deceived by her aunt and guardian and then betrayed by a friend who ruins Lilya’s reputation and consequently, her life. By a series of misunderstandings Lilya falls into prostitution and is then duped by an older man into believing a new life awaits her in the West. Once there however Lilya is forced into an array of humiliating and degrading circumstances that drive her to the brink. Set in the former Soviet Union, this is a somewhat desolate tale of dehumanisation, which contrasts starkly to the sunniness and humour of Moodyson’s “Together”, drawing on the grave themes of parent abandonment, child prostitution and human trafficking. Also available on VHS [318953].
